Description: The forepart broken from a figure of a hollow terracotta sphinx of Egyptian type, bearded, and wearing a nemes headdress with uraeus and queue. The rectangular plinth is plain. Three-piece mould. Micaceous orange-brown Nile silt, with a brown core. There is an overall white dressing, much worn.
Curator's comments: Terracotta IV Purchased 1834: Joseph Sams. Ptolemaic, third or second century BC. Comparanda: Close, probably same mould-series: Dunand 1990: no. 476, dated Roman period. Near: Allen 1985: no. 44, from Karanis, dated Ptolemaic period (?); Bayer-Niemeier 1988: nos 567 and 568, dated second to third century AD; Castiglione et al. 1978: 10, fig. 8m, acquired at Memphis, dated probably Ptolemaic; Fjeldhagen 1995: no. 65, dated Roman period; Jeffreys et al. 1988: pl. 18:c and d, from the Anubieion at Saqqara, dated Late Period or Ptolemaic; Petrie Museum uc 48008-9, from Memphis; Török 1995: no. 126; Weber 1914: no. 418, from Lower Egypt. Near, but with more detail: Ashmolean Museum, Oxford, no. 1885.170, acquired by the vendor in Medinet el-Fayum. Bibliog: Fischer 1994: 423-4, nos 1144 and 1146.
Bibliographic references: Terracotta / Catalogue of Terracottas in the British Museum (3722)
